questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, during complete lockdown, had clouding of consciousness, insomnia and visual hallucinations. He was agitated and started abusing everyone around. He was shaking and sweating profusely. Which is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delirium tremens Delirium Tremens is the Most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome which occurs within 2-4 days of abstinence from heavy alcohol drinking. It is characterized by Gross coarse tremor, Clouded consciousness , Disorientation, Visual and auditory hallucinations . Delusions, Insomnia, Dehydration, Poor attention span, agitation, ataxia, Distractibility and Autonomic disturbance (Tachycardia, hypertension, sweating) can also be seen.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Hypoactive delirium is most commonly associated with metabolic encephalopathies . It is characterized by decreased psychomotor activities and is associated with withdrawal, decreased speech and apathy . Option: C. Wernicke’s encephalopathy is characterized by delirium, ataxia and 6th nerve palsy . It is seen in B1 deficiency . It is seen in chronic alcoholics as well as in person with malabsorption syndrome Option: D. Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by memory loss, confusion and behavioural changes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old drug addict and alcoholic came to the OPD, with diarrhea, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, dilated pupil and tachycardia. After 2 days of withdrawal from his usual drug consumption. What has he been consuming, which when stopped caused the above findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Morphine The given clinical picture suggests Opioid withdrawal features . Opioid withdrawal consists of severe muscle cramps and bone aches , profuse diarrhea, abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, lacrimation , Piloerection or gooseflesh (from which comes to the term cold turkey for the abstinence syndrome), yawning, fever, pupillary dilation , hypertension, tachycardia , and temperature dysregulation, including hypothermia and hyperthermia.

Highyeild:

Morphine and heroin withdrawal syndrome Begins 6 to 8 hours after the last dose Reaches its peak intensity during the second or third day Subsides during the next 7 to 10 days , but some symptoms may persist for 6 months or longer.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Alcohol withdrawal features include seizure activity, delirium, anxiety, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and tremor . Option: C. The symptoms of nicotine withdrawal include an intense craving for tobacco, tension, irritability , difficulty concentrating, drowsiness and paradoxical trouble sleeping, decreased heart rate and blood pressure, increased appetite and weight gain, decreased motor performance, and increased muscle tension . Option: D. LSD cause no withdrawal symptoms .

questions.text: A 29-year-old male came unconscious to the casualty. He had bradycardia, pinpoint pupil, and slow respiration. There are Needle tracks in his left arm and legs and the dorsal vein of his penis. What will be your first step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adequate airway The given clinical signs point towards Opioid Overdose . The first task in overdose treatment is to ensure an adequate airway . Tracheopharyngeal secretions should be aspirated ; an airway may be inserted. The patient should be ventilated mechanically until naloxone, a specific opioid antagonist, can be given.

Highyeild:

Naloxone is administered intravenously at a slow rate Initially about 8 mg per 70 kg of body weight . Signs of improvement are: Increased respiratory rate Pupillary dilation

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - IV Naloxone immediately- not the first step Option C - Gastric lavage is not indicated in this case scenario Option D - IV fluids given after the initial airway management.

questions.text: A 37-year-old opioid addict comes to you for de-addiction. He says whenever he tries to stop himself he gets side effects. So he is forced to take it again. What treatment will you give to him?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methadone Methadone is a synthetic narcotic (an opioid) that substitutes for heroin and can be taken orally . When given to addicts to replace their usual substance of abuse , the drug suppresses withdrawal symptoms .

Highyeild:

A daily dose of 20 to 80 mg suffices to stabilize a patient, although daily doses of up to 120 mg have been used. The duration of action for methadone exceeds 24 hours ; thus, once-daily dosing is adequate.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: Option: A. Levomethadyl is an opioid agonist that suppresses opioid withdrawal . It is no longer used, however, because some patients developed prolonged QT intervals associated with potentially fatal arrhythmias (torsades de pointes). Option: C. Opioid antagonists block or antagonize the effects of opioids. Unlike methadone, they do not exert narcotic effects and do not cause dependence . Opioid antagonists include naloxone , which is used in the treatment of opioid overdose . Option: D. Naltrexone is used for alcohol dependence .

questions.text: Wernicke’s encephalopathy is characterized by delirium, ataxia, and 6th nerve palsy. All are true about Wernicke’s encephalopathy except:

options.label: A
options.text: Caused due to vitamin B1 deficiency

options.label: B
options.text: First symptom to respond after treatment is ataxia

options.label: C
options.text: Lesion is in the Mammillary body

options.label: D
options.text: Enzymes of the Krebs cycle are involved

questions.correct_answer: B. First symptom to respond after treatment is ataxia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

First symptom to respond after treatment is ataxia Wernicke encephalopathy . The patient with alcohol use disorder presents with confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (e.g, nystagmus), and gait ataxia . Thiamine deficiency leads to neuronal injury and impaired axonal conduction that cause the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy (i.e., confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia). Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a cofactor for critical enzymes involved in cerebral glucose and energy metabolism, which can be depleted in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or malnourishment. Early supplementation of thiamine would most likely have prevented this patient's condition. The first symptom to respond is ophthalmoplegia.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. it is caused due to vitamin B1 deficiency which may be due to alcoholism or malabsorption. Option: C. lesion is in the mammillary body or the dorsal medial nucleus of the thalamus Option: D. Enzymes of Krebs cycle like: E 1 PDH complex and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase are involved.

Badtrip is an adverse effect of Cannabis , in which an experience resembling the acute panic reaction to cannabis but sometimes more severe; a bad trip can occasionally produce true psychotic symptoms . Option: D. Flash-back is a sensation related to cannabis intoxication after the short-term effects of the substance have disappeared.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male consumed large amounts of bhang on Holi. Which of the following can be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Sense of slowing of time
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sense of slowing of time Bhang is a form of cannabis . Cannabis intoxication commonly heightens users’ sensitivities to external stimuli , reveals new details, makes colors seem brighter and richer, and subjectively slows the appreciation of time. In high doses , users may experience depersonalization and derealization .

Highyeild:

The most common physical effects of cannabis are dilation of the conjunctival blood vessels (red eye) and mild tachycardia . At high doses, orthostatic hypotension may appear. Increased appetite —often referred to as “the munchies”—and dry mouth are common effects of cannabis intoxication .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Increased appetite is seen Option: B . Dry eyes are seen Option: D . Everything looks bright and colorful

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought by a friend because of progressively worsening forgetfulness and frequent falls. On mental status examination, he is confused and oriented only to a person. Neurologic examination shows horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze, walks with wide-based, small steps and his gait is unsteady. Supplementation of which vitamin is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B1 This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (e.g, nystagmus), and gait ataxia . These signs and symptoms suggest Wernicke encephalopathy . Thiamine deficiency leads to neuronal injury and impaired axonal conduction that cause the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy (i.e., confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia). Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a cofactor for critical enzymes involved in cerebral glucose and energy metabolism, which can be depleted in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or malnourishment. Early supplementation of thiamine would most likely have prevented this patient's condition.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency presents clinically with megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, irritability, memory loss, and dementia . Option: C. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency presents with cheilosis, glossitis, stomatitis, sideroblastic anemia, irritability, seizures, and peripheral neuropathy . Option: D. Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency manifests clinically with pellagra , a clinical syndrome characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, glossitis, dementia , and, if not treated, death.

Solution:

The principal component is Δ9-THC and its receptor is Of Gi subtype The given plant is Cannabis Sativa . The principal component of cannabis is Δ9-THC .

This receptor is not found in the brainstem , a fact consistent with cannabis’s minimal effects on respiratory and cardiac functions. Studies have shown that cannabinoids affect the monoamine and γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) neurons .

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with alcoholism is brought by his family after they notice a decline in memory. On evaluation, the patient’s remote memory is intact, but his recent recall is severely impaired. The patient provides verbose but erroneous answers in response to questions testing recent recall. This patient’s memory distortion is most likely which form of memory disorder.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterograde amnesia This patient may be suffering from Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome , a complication of long-term alcoholism . Anterograde amnesia is the loss of immediate or short-term memory . Patients are unable to form new memories .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. Retrograde amnesia is the loss of remote or previously formed memories. Option: C. Dissociative amnesia is the loss of memory without the loss of the ability to form new memories . It is usually associated with emotional trauma and is not due to drugs or a medical condition. Option: D. Prosopagnosia is the inability to remember faces despite being able to recognize that they are faces.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a college party because of a 2-hour history of a crawling sensation under his skin. He appears anxious and is markedly pale. His temperature is 38°C, the pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoretic skin, moist mucous membranes, and dilated pupils. Which of the following substances is most likely the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cocaine Cocaine increases sympathetic activity by inhibiting the presynaptic reuptake of norepinephrine. In addition to features of sympathetic overactivity, an acute cocaine overdose can also cause hallucinations (including tactile hallucinations such as formication) and paranoid ideation .

Highyeild:

Acute cocaine overdose is treated with benzodiazepines and alpha-1 blockers (e.g., phenoxybenzamine). In the case of a suspected cocaine overdose , beta-blockers should not be used as first-line therapy because they can lead to unopposed alpha-1 receptor activation and thereby precipitate a hypertensive crisis or myocardial ischemia due to coronary vasospasm. Chronic use of cocaine can cause nasal septal hypertrophy (if used intranasally), periportal hepatitis (if ingested), myocarditis, and/or pulmonary artery hypertension.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Patients intoxicated with lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD ) classically present with vivid visual hallucinations and distorted time perception , but can also experience anxiety, agitation, and paranoid delusions . Option: C. Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can also manifest with confusion, euphoria, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, aggressive behavior, and nystagmus . However, PCP typically causes miosis . Option: D . Most patients of cannabis intoxication would present with features such as conjunctival injection, slowed time perception, and hyperphagia . Moreover, most patients with cannabis overdose would have dry mucous membranes , in contrast to this patient with moist mucous membranes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room because of a 2-hour history of increased thirst and erratic behavior after coming from a party. Her roommate reports that the patient often uses recreational drugs at parties. On arrival, the patient is diaphoretic and oriented only to the person. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), her pulse is 114/min, and her blood pressure is 156/102 mm Hg. Tremulousness and bilateral pupillary dilation were seen. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 130 mEq/L. This patient is most likely intoxicated with?

Solution:

Methylenedioxymethamphetamine This patient's increased thirst, euphoria, confusion, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis, tremor, and hyponatremia indicate intoxication with 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) .

Highyeild:

MDMA-induced hyponatremia is due to an inappropriate increase in ADH , increased thirst stimulation, and the belief of some users that the intake of large amounts of water can help prevent hyperthermia. The treatment of MDMA intoxication focuses on controlling the patient's hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, and hyponatremia .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Patients intoxicated with lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD ) classically present with vivid visual hallucinations and distorted time perception , but can also experience anxiety, agitation, and paranoid delusions . Option: C. Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can also manifest with confusion, euphoria, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, aggressive behavior, and nystagmus . However, PCP typically causes miosis . Option: D. Patients with cocaine intoxication can present with confusion, euphoria, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, tremor, and bilateral mydriasis . However, it would not explain this patient's increased thirst and hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with the complaint of fatigue. Because of his heavy drinking, he has received several reprimands at work and his wife has threatened to leave him. He drinks 6 to 12 beers a day plus several ounces of hard liquor. He reports blackouts, an inability to quit drinking, tolerance for alcohol, and likely withdrawal symptoms. He has tried to quit on several occasions but has been unable to do so. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alcohol dependence A need for daily use of large amounts of alcohol for adequate functioning, a regular pattern of heavy drinking , and long periods of sobriety interspersed with binges of heavy alcohol intake lasting for weeks or months strongly suggest alcohol dependence and alcohol abuse.

Highyeild:

The drinking patterns are often associated with certain behaviors : the inability to cut down or stop drinking ; repeated efforts to control or reduce excessive drinking by "going on the wagon" (periods of temporary abstinence) or by restricting drinking to certain times of the day.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B . The classic sign of alcohol withdrawal is tremulousness , although the spectrum of symptoms can expand to include psychotic and perceptual symptoms (e.g., delusions and hallucinations), seizures , and the symptoms of delirium tremens (DTs ), called alcohol delirium. Option: C. WERNICKE SYNDROME: An acute, usually reversible , encephalopathy resulting from a thiamine deficiency and characterized by the triad of delirium, ophthalmoplegia (typically sixth nerve), and ataxia . Option: D. DELIRIUM TREMENS: A delirium characterized by disorientation, fluctuation in the level of consciousness, elevated vital signs , and tremors as the result of an abrupt reduction in or cessation of heavy alcohol use that has lasted for a prolonged period of time.

Extraedge:

KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (PSYCHOSIS): Not actually a psychotic state but amnesia, both anterograde and retrograde amnesia , with confabulation that develops after chronic alcohol use . It is usually irreversible and is also caused by a thiamine deficiency .

questions.text: 14 hours after a surgical admission because of a broken arm, a 40-year-old woman begins to complain of feeling jittery and shaky, upset stomach, irritability, and sweating. Tremulousness (commonly called the "shakes" or the "jitters") develops 6 to 8 hours after the cessation of drinking.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy comes to the OPD with his father who is worried that his son is using drugs. According to the DSM-5 Criteria for diagnosing substance use or dependence, which of the following criteria are correct? Recurrent substance used despite of failure to fulfill obligations at work, home, school Recurrent substance use in situations in which it is physically hazardous Continued substance use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain the substance Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

" 1,2,3,4&5 All the statements are correct. "

Highyeild:

The criteria for diagnosis of substance dependence is as follows: A maladaptive pattern of substance use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress , as manifested by 2 (or more ) of the following, occurring within 12-months . Recurrent substance use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home (e.g., repeated absences or poor work performance related to substance use; substance-related absences, suspensions, or expulsions from school; neglect of children or household) Recurrent substance use in situations in which it is physically hazardous (e.g., driving an automobile or operating a machine when impaired by substance use) Continued substance use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of the substance (e.g., arguments with spouse about consequences of intoxication, physical fights) Tolerance , as defined by either of the following: A need for markedly increased amounts of the substance to achieve intoxication or desired effect. Markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of the substance. Withdrawal , as manifested by either of the following: The characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance. The same (or a closely related) substance is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms. The substance is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain the substance, use the substance, or recover from its effects Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of substance use The substance use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by the substance Craving or a strong desire or urge to use a specific substance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old chronic alcoholic, is brought to your department by his mother. She is worried and wants her son to get rid of the bad habit. Your Resident asks you to use the Cage criteria. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Scores of 1 or more strongly suggest significant alcohol problems

options.label: C
options.text: It is a screening test for alcohol dependence

options.label: D
options.text: Score of 1 doesn’t require to follow up

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a screening test for alcohol dependence
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a screening test for alcohol dependence The CAGE was developed to serve as a very brief screen for significant alcohol problems in a variety of settings, which could then be followed up by clinical inquiry.

Highyeild:

CAGE is an acronym for the four questions that comprise the instrument: Have you ever felt you should Cut down on your drinking? Have people Annoyed you by criticizing your drinking? Have you ever felt bad or Guilty about your drinking? Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or to get rid of a hangover (Eye-opener)? Each “ yes” answer is scored as 1 , and these are summed to generate a total score. Scores of 1 or more warrant follow-up . Scores of 2 or more strongly suggest significant alcohol problems .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Scores of 2 or more strongly suggest significant alcohol problems. Option: B. CAGE includes four questions Option: D. Score of 1 does require to follow up

questions.text: A 57-year alcoholic came to the OPD with memory loss, confusion, and behavior changes. Which part of his brain will have lesions most commonly?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Symmetrical mammillary bodies The given clinical Picture suggests Korsakoff psychosis which includes memory loss, confusion, and behavior changes.

Highyeild:

Wernicke’s encephalopathy and Korsakoff ’s psychosis are due to thiamine deficiency , caused either by poor nutritional habits or by malabsorption problems. Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes and may also be involved in the conduction of the axon potential along the axon and in synaptic transmission . The neuropathological lesions are symmetrical and paraventricular , involving the mammillary bodies, the thalamus, the hypothalamus , the midbrain, the pons, the medulla, the fornix, and the cerebellum .
